awd_titl_txt: Experimental Study of Cyclic Plastic Deformation Mechanisms in Hexagonal Close-Packed (HCP) Magnesium
awd_abstract_narration:
Magnesium has two-thirds the density of aluminum and is the lightest structural metal.  It is the fourth most common element on the Earth and is a green material due to its lightweight, nontoxicity, and recyclability.  Magnesium alloys, which are mixtures of magnesium with a small amount of other metals, can be used in automotive and aerospace industries to reduce fuel consumption and greenhouse gas emissions.  Structural components are often subjected to repeated loads and the resulted cyclic deformation may lead to failure of the component during operation with a catastrophic consequence.  Understanding deformation is of primary importance for engineering design.  Magnesium displays distinguishable deformation phenomena due to its atomic structure that is different from most of the other engineering structural materials.  This award supports a fundamental study of the distinct deformation in magnesium under repeated loading.  The knowledge obtained from the research will provide a base for the design of magnesium components.  The effort will promote the application of magnesium and benefit the U.S. economy and society.  The research results will be integrated into the senior design classes for undergraduate education with open-ended projects emphasizing the application of the lightweight magnesium.  

The major difference of a magnesium alloy from a conventional metal is the mechanical twinning that plays a pivotal role in deformation of the magnesium alloy.  The overall objective of the research is to explore the deformation mechanisms due to twinning/de-twinning in magnesium through carefully designed cyclic deformation experiments and microscopic observations.  A systematic study of the twinning/de-twinning deformation mechanisms will be conducted to understand nucleation and growth of twins, structures and properties of twin boundaries, twin-twin interaction, and residual twin development in magnesium under cyclic loading.  Magnesium single crystals oriented along different directions will be subjected to various cyclic loading conditions, and the material microstructures and their evolutions with applied loading cycles will be studied by using different microscopic characterizations.  Loading fixtures and extensometer will be designed to facilitate direct and accurate stress and strain measurements in small testing specimens.  The work will lead to a better understanding of deformation mechanisms in magnesium due to twinning/de-twinning and will advance modern engineering design and manufacturing.  The obtained experimental results will serve as a benchmark for the development and validation of constitutive deformation models at different material length scales.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

inst.inst_name: Board of Regents, NSHE, obo University of Nevada, Reno
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: BOARD OF REGENTS OF THE NEVADA SYSTEM OF HIGHER ED

por.por_cntn:
The NSF supported project was to enhance a fundamental understanding of deformation mechanisms in magnesium. Magnesium is the lightest structural metal and has abundant storage in the Earth crust. Being nontoxic and recyclable, magnesium alloys have a great potential to be widely applied in industry. An essential requirement for a structural material is an understanding of deformation and strength. The major difference of a magnesium from a conventional metal is the mechanical twinning that plays a pivotal role in deformation and failure of magnesium. With the development of an experimental approach combining in situ optical observation and ex situ electron backscatter diffraction, the NSF supported study answered key questions about the deformation mechanisms due to the twinning and detwinning processes in magnesium. The propagation nature of basal slip bands was directly observed for the first time, which explains inhomogeneous deformation in magnesium. In situ observations of nucleation, propagation, and interaction of twins were made. The measure crystal rotation involved in twinning was found to be in close agreement with the theoretical value. For the first time, detwinning was observed to occur during unloading, which suggests a similar cyclic plasticity behavior of twinning-detwinning to Bauschinger effect in dislocation dominant cyclic plastic deformation.  The microstructure and interaction mechanisms of twin-twin junctions were studied by combining microscopic observations and atomistic simulations.

The NSF supported project enabled direct observations of twinning and detwinning processes in magnesium when subjected to external loading. The results obtained from the project provide a benchmark and guidance for the development and validation of mechanism-based constitutive plasticity models for magnesium at atomistic and continuum length scales. A close agreement found between the directly measurement values of crystal rotations during twinning and the theoretical values is critical to validate existing atomistic theories about twinning. The molecular dynamics models validated with the experimental observed formation of twin-twin junctions allow for explorations of the twinning mechanisms at the atomistic scale for other materials. The results from the work help better understanding of fatigue mechanisms in magnesium due to twinning-detwinning and advance modern engineering design and manufacturing. 

The combined in situ optical and ex situ EBSD approach developed from the NSF project can be used for the exploration of microstructure evolution for other materials. The knowledge obtained from the project forms a foundation for developing mechanism-based models of cyclic plasticity in the design and evaluation of magnesium structures in engineering. The research work will promote the application of magnesium and benefit the U.S. economy and society.  In addition to enhancement of scientific understanding of deformation in magnesium, the NSF project supported several graduate and undergraduate students. The students received training in the use of advanced material testing and measurement equipment. The results obtained from the project forms a major part of the Ph.D. dissertation of a graduate student. An undergraduate student project was developed to make use of the twinning-detwinning plastic deformation in magnesium for damping the vibration in skis. A demonstration of the student project is available online for undergraduate education and the general public.  The NSF project allowed for the acquisition of an acid saw and modification with computer numerical control. The unique equipment is particularly suitable for fabrication of single crystal testing specimens with a curved profile, and its addition enhances the research capacity of the university.


Last Modified: 05/26/2019
Modified by: Yanyao Jiang
